abstract.p: Howard Goldberg compares 1999 alberino wine from Martin Codax with 1998 Vina Godeval by Bodegas Godeval; photo (M)

block.p: Two whites from northwestern Spain, one extroverted and the other introverted, can fuel the at-home pleasures of summer: socializing and light fish and seafood meals.

Many wine lovers, even sophisticates, barely know the kaleidoscopic treats of crowd-pleasing alberino, a flirtatiously aromatic and delicious drink, which at its best resembles weightless Mosel rieslings from Germany.
Two whites from northwestern Spain, one extroverted and the other introverted, can fuel the at-home pleasures of summer: socializing and light fish and seafood meals.

Many wine lovers, even sophisticates, barely know the kaleidoscopic treats of crowd-pleasing alberino, a flirtatiously aromatic and delicious drink, which at its best resembles weightless Mosel rieslings from Germany.

In a good vintage, like '99, alberino is addictive. One of the best versions is Martin Codax. Like all alberinos, it comes from the Rias Baixas region of Galicia. Spaniards adore it with Atlantic fish, seafood and tapas. Crisp, zesty and fresh, the '99 is tropical in flavor, with hints of coconuts and spearmint, and animated by a spritz.

By contrast, '98 Vina Godeval, made by Bodegas Godeval from the rare godello grape in the Valdeorras Valley in Galicia, is a virtually unknown, smoky, mineral-like, somewhat austere wine, which, more than alberino, wants surf fare. Its tantalizing crispness recalls Muscadet and young white Burgundies.

Martin Codax costs $13 at Rochambeau, 389 Broadway, Dobbs Ferry, and $12 at Green Lane, 741 North Bedford Road, Bedford Hills. Vina Godeval is $15 at Rockwood & Perry, 541 Warburton Avenue, Hastings-on-Hudson.
Both whites, imported and distributed by Tempranillo, in Mamaroneck, come from the portfolio of Jorge Ordonez, a broker whose Spanish estates are standard-bearers on the East Coast.
